quotes.topic_title: Impact-driven product management definition
quotes.text: ... 8:00 PM basically for me is someone that is relentless until he gets this impact, until he validates that this impact is in place.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Defines great product management as outcome validation and persistence until measurable customer impact is achieved.

quotes.topic_title: Impact-driven product management definition
quotes.text: In some cases, doing the biggest impact is not developing another feature, it's about making the current value more accessible.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that the highest-leverage work may be improving access/distribution of existing value rather than building new functionality.

quotes.topic_title: Impact-driven product management definition
quotes.text: You've been at this for eight years, you said there's 250,000 customers at this point.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides concrete scale and time horizon that frames the lessons learned from building Monday.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Daniel and the exec team realized that their competitors were able to move a lot faster than they were and ship a lot more often than they were, and that's spurred a transformation in how they build and operate their teams.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete trigger for organizational change: benchmarking execution speed and shipping cadence against competitors.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Very few companies are able to transform like this, and even fewer recognize that something is wrong.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that the hardest part of transformation is often diagnosing the need for it early enough.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Why it's important to know that the skills that got you to where you're today aren't the skills that are going to take you to the next level.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Encapsulates a key leadership mental model for scaling: success at one stage can require different capabilities at the next.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Why it's so important to orient all your teams around impact and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Points to an operating principle for product orgs: align teams to outcomes (impact) rather than activity or output.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Enterpret unifies all your customer interactions, from Gong calls, to Zendesk tickets, to Twitter threads, to App Store reviews, and makes it available for analysis.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical methodology for consolidating disparate customer feedback sources into a single analyzable system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What makes Enterpret special is its ability to build and update customer-specific AI models that provide the most granular and accurate insights into your business, connect customer insights to revenue and operational data in your CRM or data warehouse to map the business impact of each customer need and prioritize confidently, and empower your entire team to easily take action on use cases, like win-loss analysis, critical bug detection, and identifying drivers of churn, with Enterpret's AI systems wisdom.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete operating model: tailor AI to customers, tie insights to business metrics, and drive action via specific workflows (win-loss, bugs, churn).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This episode is brought to you by Airtable Product Central, the unified system that brings your entire product organization together in one place.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear organizational design principle: use a single system of record to align the full product org.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of it as mission control for your entire product organization.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how a unified product system should function day-to-day.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And because it's built on Airtable's no-code platform, you can customize every workflow to match exactly how your team works.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to prioritize adaptable tooling so processes can fit the team rather than forcing the team to fit the tool.

quotes.topic_title: Competitor shock: realizing Monday shipped too slowly
quotes.text: And, this morning, we actually saw that one of our main competitors back then has actually launched 30 new columns.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A concrete competitive benchmark that triggered Monday’s realization they were shipping far too slowly.

quotes.topic_title: Competitor shock: realizing Monday shipped too slowly
quotes.text: Because, I remember back then, when we did a conversation, we said, "Okay. We're doing so much. What is the most meaningful thing that we did over the last three months?" And suddenly, the answer was, "There's so many things." But it wasn't something specific.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic question for focus: lots of activity without a single meaningful outcome signals a prioritization problem.

quotes.topic_title: Competitor shock: realizing Monday shipped too slowly
quotes.text: So we said, "Okay, we need to take upon ourselves an ambitious goal, like 25 columns in one month." And this is the goal that we took upon ourselves.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: An example of using an aggressive, time-boxed goal to force a different operating model and execution approach.

quotes.topic_title: Competitor shock: realizing Monday shipped too slowly
quotes.text: And if you can't answer that and you say, "Listen, I'm doing so much." But you can't point this exact thing, you have a focus problem in my eyes.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A blunt rule-of-thumb for leaders: inability to name a transformative outcome indicates lack of focus despite high effort.

quotes.topic_title: Competitor shock: realizing Monday shipped too slowly
quotes.text: Use your competition, know it, use it to your advantage, and take it, and set ambitious goals, and believe in yourself, and you can do amazing things.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A practitioner-oriented mantra for turning competitor pressure into a forcing function for ambition and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and the columns hackathon playbook
quotes.text: I think, by the way, this is something which is really important about setting ambitious goals. If you set a different goal, "I want to reduce it from four months to three months." So many times, this translates in people's heads to, "I want you to work harder. I want you to work longer hours." And, this is not a message here. It's about working smarter.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Clarifies why “slightly better” goals often drive burnout, while truly ambitious goals force smarter system changes.

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and the columns hackathon playbook
quotes.text: Many times when we talk about speed of execution, there's fake speed, which means, trying to do the same work by skipping stages or not doing the high quality that you want, but there's the real speed, and speed of organizations, and speed of execution. Many times, it's about doing things right.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Introduces a useful mental model—fake speed vs real speed—to guide how teams accelerate without quality collapse.

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and the columns hackathon playbook
quotes.text: I think, one of the best benefits for us as platform is that suddenly when we set the goal of adding so many different columns, we actually stopped for the first time and say, "What is the column like?" And we also organized all the product architecture around it.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Shows how an aggressive goal can force teams to define primitives and reorganize architecture around reusable building blocks.

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and the columns hackathon playbook
quotes.text: The way we actually achieved it is that we said, "Okay. In two weeks, we're going to have a hackathon, in which, each one of our developers is going to take one column and implement it in one day." And, if you think about it, from four months to one day, it's mind-blowing.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A concrete execution playbook (hackathon + one-dev-one-ship) with a striking before/after speed benchmark.

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and the columns hackathon playbook
quotes.text: I think that for the goals, this is why we really wanted the goal that you really understand from the first minute that if you work the same way, you cannot achieve it, even if you sleep in the office. So you need to change dramatically how you think.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A practical criterion for setting goals: pick targets that make “work harder” impossible and “work differently” mandatory.

quotes.topic_title: Orienting teams around measurable impact
quotes.text: So in many ways PM in Monday, first and foremost, is responsible for creating the shared understanding on what would be impactful for our customers. Okay? It's not about the solution and what we are going to build. It's about, what's the problem, what's the opportunity. And second, how we will know that we moved the needle.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Defines a clear PM accountability framework: align on customer impact, clarify the problem/opportunity, and pre-commit to measurable success criteria.

quotes.topic_title: Orienting teams around measurable impact
quotes.text: So PMs and the teams, many times, spending a lot of time at the problem area, before they think about the solution. The solution is not the case anymore. There are so many different solutions.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A practical methodology shift: invest heavily in problem understanding because solutions are abundant and interchangeable until validated.

quotes.topic_title: Orienting teams around measurable impact
quotes.text: And, once you do that and you have these goals, suddenly, it reduces also a lot of the discussions that you have about the different solutions, because everyone knows that everything is going to be tested in real life.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Shows how measurable goals act as a decision filter, replacing opinion debates with real-world tests.

quotes.topic_title: Orienting teams around measurable impact
quotes.text: And then, in some cases, doing the biggest impact is not developing another feature. It's about making the current value more accessible. It's about connecting better the go-to market motion that you have. It's about understanding how your customers are going to learn what you built and use it.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Counterintuitive impact lever: the highest ROI work may be distribution/discoverability and go-to-market alignment rather than new feature development.

quotes.topic_title: Orienting teams around measurable impact
quotes.text: And, it's hard, because people tend to build things. We all love to build things. And, when you start to build things, you get excited, and suddenly, you lose track of why you are doing it, and why do you need to change.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A memorable warning about a common failure mode: shipping momentum can detach teams from the original customer-impact rationale.

quotes.topic_title: Smells of non-impact work and AI Blocks example
quotes.text: I think, the most obvious sign for me is that you are building something without the aim or without the initial aim of what it changed for your users and how you are going to measure it.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A crisp diagnostic for “non-impact work”: building without a measurable user change defined upfront.

quotes.topic_title: Smells of non-impact work and AI Blocks example
quotes.text: Many times, for me, a smell for that is that I hear people use the word, "We're going to enhance..." "We're going to augment..." "We're going to extend value, and this, and this, and this." No, it's not enough. What is it going to change for users and how you are going to see it that it actually happened?
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A memorable “smell test” for vague goals, and a push toward explicit outcomes + measurement.

quotes.topic_title: Smells of non-impact work and AI Blocks example
quotes.text: So each team at Monday has, what we call, the daily numbers update.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A concrete operating mechanism for staying close to metrics and making impact visible daily.

quotes.topic_title: Smells of non-impact work and AI Blocks example
quotes.text: And one day, we saw, we noticed that the amount of accounts that are using AI is super, super low comparing to the entire population that we have. And we have 250,000 paying companies that use Monday, and we saw only few thousands there.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A specific data point showing how metric visibility can reveal adoption gaps even when qualitative feedback is strong.

quotes.topic_title: Smells of non-impact work and AI Blocks example
quotes.text: And with two weeks time, it was open to 98% of Monday customers.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A high-leverage example of removing a non-product blocker (TOS gating) to unlock impact quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Working-backwards planning rituals at company and team level
quotes.text: but how do I imagine the company and the product is going to be different and better for our customers in a quarter from now? And from that, walk it backwards.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A simple working-backwards planning ritual that forces teams to start from customer impact and reverse-engineer priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Working-backwards planning rituals at company and team level
quotes.text: But if you are just saying, "We'll have better security. We'll have better performance. We'll have less bugs. We'll have more enhancements to," I don't know, "this and this feature," it's not enough. You need to constantly build value, which is pivotal to your customers.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A warning against defaulting to internal quality metrics instead of defining customer-pivotal value.

quotes.topic_title: Working-backwards planning rituals at company and team level
quotes.text: And if you don't do it and if it's hard for you to answer about this question, it's a very good sign that you are not impact-driven.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A diagnostic test: if you can’t articulate meaningful customer change, you’re likely not operating with impact focus.

quotes.topic_title: Working-backwards planning rituals at company and team level
quotes.text: I really like to have a slide in which I write and I just share it, " When I'm going to stand here in a year from now, what is going to be different for our customers?"
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A concrete company-level mechanism (an annual “next year” slide) to institutionalize working backwards.

quotes.topic_title: Working-backwards planning rituals at company and team level
quotes.text: So I really encourage to create these points in time where you sit down and you force yourself to understand whether what you did is what you thought you are going to achieve or not.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A cadence-based reflection practice (e.g., biweekly written updates) to continuously audit impact vs. intent.

quotes.topic_title: Monday’s scale today and why work tools matter
quotes.text: We recently announced that we cost the 1 billion in ARR, and we are serving, as I said, 250,000 customers across the globe from virtually any industry that you can think about, more than 200 different business verticals.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Concrete scale metrics that anchor what “mass adoption” looks like for a work-management tool across industries.

quotes.topic_title: Monday’s scale today and why work tools matter
quotes.text: Just for reference, in a single [inaudible 00:33:06], when I joined Monday eight and a half years ago, back then, we were called the Pulse. We had around 4 million in ARR, and we scaled from there to 1 billion. And from around 30, 40 people in the company to 2,500 right now.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A before/after snapshot that illustrates the magnitude of scaling from early-stage to global company size.

quotes.topic_title: Monday’s scale today and why work tools matter
quotes.text: If you really boil down what are they doing day-to-day, they're sitting in tools like Monday, putting together tasks, and doing to-dos, and sharing documents. This is what the world runs on.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A reframing mental model: even the most advanced industries run on mundane execution workflows, making work tools foundational infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: Monday’s scale today and why work tools matter
quotes.text: You would get into our office and you would see a dashboard with how many paying accounts do you have, how many people have churned today, how many signups do we have, and so many different things. Even if you came for an interview, you would see these numbers.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A specific operational practice for radical transparency—making key business metrics visible to employees (and even candidates).

quotes.topic_title: Counterintuitive lesson: radical transparency at scale
quotes.text: And instead of demoralizing people, I think that, for the right people and the people that are working at Monday, this is something that gives them a sense of deep partnership.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Reframes the common fear that sharing bad news hurts morale, arguing transparency can increase ownership and partnership.

quotes.topic_title: Counterintuitive lesson: radical transparency at scale
quotes.text: We really want everyone's brains in the challenge and not just one centralized brain and a lot of working hands.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A memorable operating model for scaling problem-solving by distributing context broadly, not just tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Counterintuitive lesson: radical transparency at scale
quotes.text: And I remember cases in which someone said, "Listen, what happened to the conversion?" And think how powerful it is when you have everyone at the company looking at these things.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Concrete example of how visible metrics prompt proactive detection and discussion of issues across the org.

quotes.topic_title: Counterintuitive lesson: radical transparency at scale
quotes.text: So I think that maybe the counterintuitive part is that don't be afraid to share the information. It's exactly the other way around.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Direct, actionable advice that challenges the default instinct to restrict information when things get tough.

quotes.topic_title: Counterintuitive lesson: radical transparency at scale
quotes.text: So, now, if I'll fast-forward, we're almost four years public, and we have an internal app called Monday Morning. And in Monday Morning, you have two parts, part A and part B. Part A is for every company employee, contains a lot about engagement and a lot of data that can be shared with everyone, and part B is confidential and it's by role, okay?
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A practical methodology for maintaining radical transparency at scale (and as a public company) via role-based access.

quotes.topic_title: How to start transparency: dashboards and daily numbers
quotes.text: When we were very small back in the days, we had the daily numbers concept that we now have for the teams, we had the daily numbers for the company, how much paying accounts, how many upgraded, downgrade, and so on daily, and you saw people reacting to it on a daily basis.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A concrete, lightweight starting practice for transparency: publish daily company metrics so everyone can react in real time.

quotes.topic_title: How to start transparency: dashboards and daily numbers
quotes.text: So this is something that you can do in virtually one hour, and it changes how people see their role within the company, focus everyone to the company's KPIs because everyone understand what you care about, and so on.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A time-boxed tactic with outsized impact: a quick metrics share can immediately align the org around what matters.

quotes.topic_title: How to start transparency: dashboards and daily numbers
quotes.text: And the second thing which is really practical, it's the office dashboards. We really believe in it. So, you buy a TV, you put it on the wall, you start a conversation due to it, "What do we want to show on this TV?"
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A simple methodology for making metrics visible and forcing prioritization: public dashboards that spark ongoing KPI conversations.

quotes.topic_title: How to start transparency: dashboards and daily numbers
quotes.text: We programmed it to have sounds on meaningful events.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A memorable operational trick: use audible cues to make key metrics part of the company’s daily cadence.

quotes.topic_title: How to start transparency: dashboards and daily numbers
quotes.text: But in many companies, only the management or the founders are feeling.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about motivation: sharing wins broadly creates partnership and changes the quality of conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So we started Vanta in 2018 focused on founders, helping them start to build out their security programs and get credit for all of that hard security work with compliance certifications, like SOC 2 or ISO 27001.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: Highlights a practical approach: pair security work with recognized certifications to make it legible and valuable to customers and the market.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Today, we currently help over 9,000 companies, including some startup household names, like Atlassian RAMP and LangChain, start and scale their security programs, and ultimately build trust by automating compliance, centralizing GRC, and accelerating security reviews.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: Provides a concrete scale data point and a three-part methodology for building trust: automate compliance, centralize GRC, and speed up security reviews.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: That is very much our experience before the company, and to some extent, during it, but the idea is, with automation, with AI, with software, we are helping customers build trust with prospects and customers in an efficient way.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: Frames compliance/security as a trust-building function that can be made efficient through automation and AI rather than manual process.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And our joke, we started this compliance company so you don't have to.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: A memorable, product-positioning mental model: outsource the pain of compliance by turning it into software.

quotes.topic_title: Bold bets: launching five products at once
quotes.text: We actually announced five different new products simultaneously on the same time, and we had so many... I can't stress enough how hard it is to think about it.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A concrete example of a deliberately bold GTM strategy—shipping a multi-product suite all at once instead of iterating one product at a time.

quotes.topic_title: Bold bets: launching five products at once
quotes.text: So many different concerns, but we decided to do it because we really want to create a pivotal leap.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A decision-making principle: accept short-term confusion and operational complexity to pursue step-change outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Bold bets: launching five products at once
quotes.text: And some of them we understood that they don't need to be separate products and we collapse them back to the main product.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: An actionable portfolio approach: launch multiple bets, then consolidate what doesn’t merit standalone product status.

quotes.topic_title: Bold bets: launching five products at once
quotes.text: But looking back it's such, I'm so happy with this move and the fact that we did it like that because just imagine what would happen if we would choose one of them and it wasn't the successful products. And our conclusion can be that multi product won't work for us.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lesson about avoiding false negatives by not over-indexing on a single bet when testing a new strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Bold bets: launching five products at once
quotes.text: not taking bold risks, not making bold moves, it's a risk for itself. Okay?
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A memorable reframing practitioners can use to justify leap-style decisions when incrementalism is the default.

quotes.topic_title: Taking risks and avoiding over-polish (partial)
quotes.text: Not taking a risk is a big risk.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concise reframing that inaction and incrementalism can be riskier than making bold bets.

quotes.topic_title: Taking risks and avoiding over-polish (partial)
quotes.text: And looking back and what have we even done? What have we done over this year of hard work and tons of features?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical gut-check for teams shipping lots of work without meaningful progress or excitement.

quotes.topic_title: Taking risks and avoiding over-polish (partial)
quotes.text: I really believe that many time, like spending more time on working on something will not yield to better results or to better products.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning against over-polishing and equating more effort/time with better outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Taking risks and avoiding over-polish (partial)
quotes.text: And I think this is a very bad feedback to get for initial things that you are doing.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: Challenges the common desire for praise early on, implying early products should optimize for learning over admiration.

quotes.topic_title: Taking risks and avoiding over-polish (partial)
quotes.text: But actually we really encourage people to get really fast production, to put traps for themselves that is called by time and not by effort.
quotes.speaker: Daniel Lereya
quotes.context: An actionable methodology: use time constraints (deadlines) rather than effort as a forcing function to ship and learn faster.
